headline: World-class universities, but mediocre support and poorly designed website
reviewBody:
I've completed several classes with edX. The content of the courses was excellent, but there are some serious flaws with the website and the support team that leads to a poor user experience for learners. This experience means it will be unlikely I will purchase any future courses from them.

First, the website is simply not designed well:
- It's difficult to browse for new course titles. 
- You cannot save courses for later. 
- The "Dashboard" lists all of the courses you've taken, regardless of whether the course was completed. If you un-enroll from a course, it won't appear on the Dashboard, but you cannot take it the course again until the next "session" or if you pay (maybe).
- Courses cannot be archived.
- If you complete a course, you cannot share achievement page that shows up after finishing the course.
- There is also no link to the main course page, where you originally enrolled.

Another website flaw is that after a course has expired, you can no longer view the home screen for that course. The home screen is the page you go after enrolling. That page has all the dates you need to know for the course, so if you no longer have access, you cannot get the dates. The problem here is that although a course has expired, there is still time to upgrade to a verified certificate. But since each course has its own deadline, you need to access the home screen for each course to learn this information. 

The support staff leaves a lot to be desired. In my case, I took a few classes but did not upgrade while I considered if it was worth the money, which is/was limited. Eventually, the course expired, but the website still gave me the option to upgrade. I wanted to know how much time I had left to consider my options, before my access to upgrade would expire, but the site does not provide dates for when this post-course/pre-upgrade period ends. So I contacted their support team to learn how I could find out when my course would expire. After submitting my question, I had a 14+ email exchange with someone on their support who repeatedly told me I could "upgrade to the verified track by paying the fee" or enroll in the the next session. At one point, they said I could view the course's homepage to find this information. But when I asked for an explanation on how to view the course homepage after my access to a course has expired, they support staff began sending progressively worse messages. Instead of addressing their own suggestion, they simply copied and pasted responses from their FAQ, no regard to how well the response actually answered my question. They even left a final message that was literally an overview of how edX works, "edX is a non-profit massive open online course provider...." Condescending, in other words. There is still no date available on the dashboard, which would answer my question. It's basic sales psychology. The least they could say is, "Sorry that feature isn't available right now", or something remotely helpful along those lines. 

My conclusion is that when their support staff cannot answer the question, they've been given orders to not provide answers outside of a narrow set of responses, regardless of how well the response provides value or a solution. 

The other thing that doesn't make sense is their enrollment/expiration policy. For instance, un-enrolling from a course means you cannot re-enroll until the course is offered again. However, when you view a course's overview page (found after searching), it will show you that the course begins on whatever date is today. But, if you go to your Dashboard, you will see no record of having ever taken the course. There are other issues I could go into, but those are some of the main errors I've seen. 

It's a shame some really world-class universities are associated with a mediocre support team and poorly designed website. The content is really fantastic, but dealing with the website and the support team is very challenging.

headline: Thin unstructured content and tech not working
reviewBody:
The courses: 
I have done a course with Harvard  and one with Smithsonian. 
Both times the content was thin and unstructured.
I have seen more professional content by some YouTubers than I have on these courses.
The study time estimates are a complete joke: one course had 7 hrs to 35 hrs study (in itself not very helpful). Would you believe it had 60 hours of film to watch, 20 recommended books and 15 assignments to submit? Did I mention you had to have a blog or create a website for it and do social media posting at every step? More like 100 hours of work minimum.

The platform:
- The tech is at best tedious and at worse not working at all.
- Moving from one page to another takes time and it is the only way to get an overview of the course (to gage your study time).
- Some parts of the course are missing from the syllabus and will only appear as you progress (too bad if you are approaching the deadline)
- For some courses, the units will not mark as complete (even if you have done all the work and submitted 5 times). If you get in touch with the helpdesk, they respond "it will not affect you, the teacher doesn't look at that"... then you check their FAQ and see that that it is totally the opposite: because your units aren't showing as complete you are not going to get graded at all.
Then you check Trustpilot and see that other's work never got graded and people never got their certificate, despite contacting the helpdesk AND the relevant university.
After a second ticket raised with the helpdesk and 10 emails, i'm still trying to get the entirety of my work graded.

Essentially these courses are a Windows of marketing for the universities and institutions on the platform. They'll even use you to do loads of social media posting for them as mandatory to submit your coursework.
If all you want is a certificate from a prestigious institution (and you are lucky with the technology and are unconcerned about learning or being treated as a human by the helpdesk), then this platform may be for you.
If you are serious about learning and would like some respect, it is not.

headline: Very unreasonable
reviewBody:
I added an extra star for the effort the teachers went through to record the lecture videos, because the visuals help with learning the concepts. But that's about where it ends. 
This was my second attempt at completing a particular course (free version) relevant to my current university studies. During the first attempt, I admittedly didn't manage my time well, and I only completed 3 of the 6 weeks before I lost my access to the course. I was bummed but I moved on. Months later, I see the same course has become available again. I had to start from scratch and do all the tests again from week 1 (I want to achieve a passing grade). I knew the due date was 3 May, so I worked hard to get to the end of the course this time. As I logged on for what I planned to be my last session just before 8am on 3 May, I found I no longer had access. Apparently EdX (in contrast to the rest of the world) defines a 3 May closing date as a "midnight on 2 May" due date. This is no doubt part of their plan to force people to buy the (very overpriced) 'verified certificate', because it's the only way we won't lose all our progress, and most people do use that last day to complete these online courses. 
I'm so frustrated. I've poured HOURS of valuable time into this course (3 'weeks' the first time and 5 'weeks' the second time) and I have squat to show for it. Not even the meaningless free certificate. I emailed the support and begged to give me just two more hours of access, since their due date was very misleading. They said no of course. Then I applied for the financial support to pay for the verified certificate, which they rejected.
I wouldn't recommend EdX to anyone. I have completed free and verified courses on Coursera and I haven't had any issues.

headline: No Certification After Course-End
reviewBody:
edX has a policy in which you have to complete and pass all course assignments by the course-end date. After the course-end date, the course becomes "archived," in which you can no longer continue working on assignments for a verified certificate.  This policy makes it a complete waste of money for extremely busy professionals and college students.  Other online learning platforms are better than edX as it allows people to work at their own pace for a certificate, even after missed course deadlines.  In addition, other learning platforms allow learners to reset missed deadlines to receive a certification.  However, edX's policy of completing all assignments by the course date for a certificate is a money-making scheme. I wish edX allowed learners to continue working on course assignments for certification, even after the course-end date.

In addition, the user-experience on edX is poorly designed as it is difficult to navigate through the pages. 0/10 would recommend.

reviewBody: I've taken several edX courses and have observed three things in my studies. (1) The quality of the courses vary greatly. Some are top notch and others are rubbish. When my proctored exam wasn't functioning the only help they gave me was to suggest using an updated OS and browser and ensuring my WiFi connection was stable, none of which addressed the specific issue I was facing. For another class I paid for a certificate and completed all the coursework, but never received a certificate. I contacted both edX and the course provider, HarvardX. HardvardX confirmed I completed the course and sent my info to edX, but edX insisted I work with HarvardX to resolve. I've only ever received completely useless, boilterplate responses when contacting support.

headline: So so bad
reviewBody:
So so bad. I get that the individual academic provider would contribute to the experience (in this case I studied the University of Maryland Micromasters which was absolute rubbish - no engagement with staff, no proof-reading of exam content, ambiguous questions, highly questionable academic integrity), but edx is not much better. There was consistent bugs with the platform, throughout all courses and the exams (someone in the forum mentioned that they'd paid to take the course 3 times after failing the exam multiple times, and they were still unable to get feedback). When I asked for a copy of my exam so I could at least see where I need to improve, they said they couldn't provide it for "reasons of academic integrity" and were not willing to provide any further feedback.

Furthermore, all of this was close to the 6 month point where I could still request a refund. I decided to wait until I could find out their response to my questions before cancelling in case they genuinely seemed to care about the student experience (they didn't), and due to the fact that I had to follow-up no-reply's several times, the refund period lapsed by 1 week. Any company with a integrity would look past this but not edx - they denied the refund.

headline: Never got my certificate due to an administration error on their side
reviewBody: I enrolled in a course about circular economy. The course was great and I was offered the chance to pay for a certificate (verified track). I paid for this, after which the tests and exams would become available for me. However, only then it became clear that the deadline for the exams had already passed (even before I enrolled the course). I sent an e-mail to tell them that I paid for something I would never receive and they sent me a reply that they fixed the problem for me. Indeed, the deadlines for the exams had shifted to a later date and I could take them all. After I finished the course, I still didn't get my certificate. I e-mailed again to the customer service and they now explained they had enrolled me in a later version of the course, which hadn't even started yet, and the only option for me was to wait for that new course to start and to retake all of my exams, tests and essays. I paid for a certificate, I finished all my exams, I passed the course, and then they tell my I have to redo it all again in order to actually get my certificate and that there was nothing they could do. Since I didn't intend to re-invest all of this time due to an administration error on their side, I asked for a refund, but didn't get a reply.

headline: Stay away from edX!!!
reviewBody:
This is the first time I am writing a negative review in my life.
Two main issues I have encountered with edX:
1. Course content is horrible
2. ID verification process is terrible

Course content is horrible:
I took "C++ Introduction", I completed the course in just 3 hours and learned nothing, honestly nothing!
There is no any hands-on practice, no any useful videos. There are videos on the background of C++, how it evolved, what has changed from the previous versions and so on. Crap who needs this???
 
ID verification process is terrible:
I planned to strengthen my IT foundation skills and decorate my shelf with a lot of IT certs in 2020. For this reason, I paid for the course. My ID verification has failed 4 times so far, because the system only allows to take a selfie shots. No attachments or front camera options enabled. What a poor service and very bad user experience!

Conclusion:
Overall, I have got nothing but stress from edX. I lost the followings:
-4 hours of my precious time
-99$ USD 
-4 times ID verification submitted
Money gone, time gone, no skill or cert gained!!! What a disaster service edX. Good game, well played!

I have also submitted verification info to their platform for the purposes of obtaining the course certificates. I recently managed to signup for a course that didn’t have a current start date and contacted support about it. There was a small delay in replying (I put that down to the current COVID-19 issue and people working remotely). The support replied with the info that there was not a current start date but I could be kept informed as to when a new date became available. I asked how to get a refund instead. I went through the refund process, which was actually very easy (cog icon on course section on my home page to leave the course) and the money was refunded to my credit card  in a few days. I initially contacted them within 24 hours of signing up so this may have been a factor in my refund. This organisation is totally legitimate and worth considering for online learning.

headline: The HarvardX Data Science program…
reviewBody:
The HarvardX Data Science program seemed underdeveloped.

Courses were launched before they were ready, some were half-finished as a result, others were delayed months, (including the tightly-deadlined capstone project), causing major disruption to learners. 

TAs were unresponsive on the message board, and assessments had major errors in the grading system, and didn't account for very differences between R installations that might result in (statistically) immaterial differences in expected answers. As far as the video lectures, it was apparent that Dr. Irrizarry was reading off a teleprompter and not fully engaged with what he was saying, with awkward intonation and emphasis, and not fully utilizing the visual medium. The course had inconsistent expectations of learners' understanding of statistics and calculus, sometimes explaining concepts very basically, and at other times glossing over graduate-level concepts.

Some courses had major swings in complexity. Data Wrangling could be done in an afternoon, while Machine Learning could easily take days or weeks. The capstone project was poorly scoped, and inconsistently graded.

edX was only too happy to take my money upfront though.

Ultimately, I learned a lot and feel the professional certificate is valuable, and I have no problem working hard to learn a new concept. But it felt like I spent more time fighting poor course design than than I was investing in my learning.

Lesson learned: don't take (or at least don't pay for) a professional certificate course the first year it is offered.

headline: I love the edX learning environment
reviewBody:
I love the edX learning environment.  LOTS of choices.  I can find a course on whatever interests me.  My only niggle is that sometimes (speaking specifically about so Microsoft offerings) the course material has not kept up with the application.  This causes students to have to figure out what the instructor(s) are talking about to arrive at the correct answer or use a process.  Another thing.  In one instance, I felt that the curriculum failed miserably at preparing me for the final in the course.  For example, the course labs were kind of fill in the blank, fairly easy, and were not comprehensive.  The final in the course asked LOTS of stuff that I was not prepared to answer. headline: edX: key player in the new learning generation
reviewBody:
The edX organization—together with its other efforts, such as Open edX—is the key player among the next generation of learners. Today, edX has the power to shape a new standard of education, lifelong learning, and professional development. And, while doing so, delivering a service that affects learners at a societal scale. In the future, their efforts could shift towards adding incentives for high-disparity, low-income, and PPP-deficient nations. If well implemented, these emerging and developing economies stand to benefit the most from wide access to quality education.

Knowingly, in some cases, edX already offers financial aid. However, the issue can sometimes be cultural! Learners need to value education, and this comes not only via democratizing access to knowledge, but also by outspoken authoritative statements on the fruits of education, and efforts to publicize the activities of organizations such as edX.

headline: Really disappointed with the platform.
reviewBody:
Really disappointed with the platform.

For the course I took, the course content was poorly delivered, but that's not on them.

The third party platform they use for grading didn't accept correct responses but that's also not on them.

What is on them is having arbitrary deadlines to complete paid for, self-paced online work, giving no warning when the time is about to expire, and then forcing students to pay for the course again to complete them. Not cheap either when compared to the same types of courses offered on other platforms ($99 for a SQL course, when a higher caliber one is available through Udemy for $10.)

No phone number to contact so you have to go back and forth via email to discuss issues, and each response takes at least a day if not more. 

Overall, I'll complete the current courses I'm enrolled in, never spend money on them again, and will tell anyone who asks to avoid. To say the behaviour is unacceptable is a gross understatement.

Edit: a rep from EdX replied below, but I dont believe his response addresses the bulk of the issue: comparatively overpriced courses with arbitrary deadlines, poor quality customer support without option to call and no level of proactivity in their simplistic "the deadline passed (no other info on next steps)" responses, having to redo all of the course content if you miss said deadline, etc.

I've clearly already reached out to the support team, given the content of this review, so the advice to do so again will get me nowhere. Any reader may take this as an example of the caliber of service they can expect from this platform.

headline: The platform has a VERY SERIOUS ISSUE that could result in you not getting your final certificate!
reviewBody:
The platform has a VERY SERIOUS ISSUE that could result in you not getting your final certificate!

The learning experience is fine. It offers videos and text. 
However, on the course I paid for, and took time off from my employer to do, it was clearly stated on the course description that ALL assignments were due by the end of the course. However the last two major homework assignments had expired before the end of the course resulting in a zero grade on both. This is a very serious mistake that shouldn't be allowed by the platform, because if those 2 assignments which I got a zero on, managed to lower my overall average below the passing grade, then this would have created an even bigger problem for me with my employer since then I wouldn't have been able to present a final certificate.

This is a very serious issue which Edx tried to put the blame for on the course staff, but as the platform which hosts the courses, they should enforce the rules set forth by the very course descriptions and not allow course staff to break their own rules.

headline: Avoid if you can!
reviewBody:
No support offered - out of date/incompatible materials issued to complete courses.

Unfortunately this is the official provider of a course that I want to complete and there are no other options available. I am now 8 units in and have faced multiple issues with the course content being incompatible with environments that they have issued. 

Contacting EDX results in "we can't help you, ask others taking the course or fix it yourself and if you go past our quarterly mandated renewal window you will have to pay another $99". Not sure why they have to re-issue the course every 3 months given that all materials are the same again, think it may have something to do with it costing $99 each time(!)

I would not recommend this provider to anyone, I wish I did not have to use them myself. Having used various providers previously for learning I can say this is the worst so far.

headline: I have a MA in history  and have…
reviewBody: I have a MA in history  and have already done some statistical analysis for my course work and at my day job.  I took Analytics for Decision Making and i cannot recommend this course.   I had a few questions for the staff and they were not timely in responding. In another case i sent an email to the wrong staff - do you think they had the common sense to say something like "...You sent your request to the wrong department but we forwarded it on for you - here is who you should contact in the future for these type requests." No they did not. Additionally, the instructor for the classification tree did not show how he arrived at his work on the second 12 minute 48 second video - instead, he droned on for both videos as if reading from a script - it was evident he did not feel compelled to rehearse - it showed badly.  All in all i get the impression that all of the instructors are only in it for the buck and consequently are not concerned about content and delivery.  Personally, this was a huge waste of time and $

headline: Great course, poor exam experience
reviewBody: The quality of the courses are generally very good. Unfortunately, trying to take the final exam is often a terrible experience. The technical requirements for the exam software are very specific. I have so far managed to take one edX final exam (after several hours of trying). I have attempted another but, despite trying on three different computers over a period of two weeks, I could not get the exam software to work and so have now failed my course. I must have spent several hours in discussion with the IT team where I work but still could not get a chance to sit the exam. Very disappointed as I have enjoyed all the courses I have taken with edX.

headline: Very poor customer service
reviewBody: Very poor customer service, it takes ages for them to respond to an email. Their platform was down at the time of the test for a course I had paid 200$ and was showing a message that the edx staff were working to fix it. I emailed them immediately sending them print screens as a proof of the issue asking them to solve it asap and 2 days later they responded that their platform hadn't met any issues. So I got zero without being even able to access the test. In another case I had already started a course for 3 weeks and wanted to pay for it but they had forgotten to mention that there was a cut off time. They had only stated the date. So the registrations suddenly closed at 15:00UTC with no prior notification. I find them quite unprofessional, they don't respect us as customers and they expose the Universities that use them. Some of the teaching materials provided are very good, but the Universities should move them into their own platforms and leave edX because it is very unreliable.

headline: Worse MOOC platform I ever used!
reviewBody:
I am taking Micro Masters, upgraded to verified. It took 10 days to get it updated on edx. I had to email for almost everything. 

Now, I am already half way in my first course, I noticed I don't have "option to choose the session" for other courses : automatically enrolled in current session. 

There are too many restrictions and rules: beware before you enroll.  If it is MOOC, should be flexible. Most of the people taking MOOC courses are WORKING professionals.

Support replies without reading the problem!!!!!! I am wasting more time with support than using in study.

Contents are good, platform is a waste.

headline: edX forever!
reviewBody:
edX is truly an awesome platform for engaging in lifelong learning.
Right from the sheer range of subjects and topics, to the superb quality and caliber of both the course contents and the institutions offering the the courses – truly a boon. 
What they've achieved, in addition to making fantastic learning resources globally accessible, in many ways has redefined the education in itself, whether one seeks enrichment for the sheer curiosity and pursuit of knowledge, or as a means to build a professional/academic path. Personally, I am moving across disciplines and consequently there are gaps in my understanding and competence in certain areas. I have found edX and the very many hosted courses to be invaluable in filling out these blind spots, enabling a deeper appreciation of the disciplines involved. I have gained more structured knowledge efficiently and along with it, confidence, than I would have if I had relied only on books. 
Most courses that I have taken have far exceeded my expectations, some more so than others. One can easily experience the joy of learning in whichever domain one fancies! Even if there ever were moments of dissatisfaction, they were addressed by either the platform or by the course makers or the discussion groups. 
The very fact that all courses on the platform are open to everyone regardless of financial investments – speaks volumes about edX's commitment to the cause.
Thank you for existing and please don't ever stop!

headline: Grader/TA issues mar an otherwise positive experience
reviewBody:
I appreciate the learning experiences edX has allowed me to access and plan to keep using it. However, there have been serious issues with several courses I have taken, and I also disapprove of many emails I have received.

Multiple courses have major automatic grading issues, especially regarding specific answer input format that is not specified in the question. Sometimes question wording is an issue. Some TAs have gone as far as to apologize on the message board to those who mentioned the issue, then say they will specifically review that person's answer and adjust the grade, but that person may be one of hundreds with the same issue and it is not fair to change one person's grade while not touching the faulty grader code and not revisiting every single person's answer that was correct but falsely rejected (obviously not feasible and thus extra unfair to fix one person only).

There is also very, very little staff/community TA support on message boards for most courses I have taken. I just signed up to be a community TA for a future version of the course, and understand now this may be because the contract I had to sign discouraged interaction on the message board on order to force the learner community to be self-sustaining. While understandable, this is NOT reasonable when many issues are beyond learner comprehension level or involve structural issues with the course (such as grader complaints or unclear question wording).

headline: Professional Qalifications Available Now... (but not really)
reviewBody:
I enrolled on the Data Science Professional Certificate in March 2018. This is where you take 9 courses on a 'track' and recieve a qualification when you complete them all.

At the time only a few courses had been released, but all the release dates were given and the final course should have been released in July. Then some of the course dates went back... then they went back again... and again... Each time a release date rolls around you log in, and it's just gone back another month. No emails, no apologies, no explanations on the forums, nothing! 

We're now in November and the current (not the last) course on the track is being released in bits. The final course may not be released this year and the current may actually expire without being fully released - meaning no qualification!

This is a QUALIFICATION!!! I paid for a qualification which is supposed to help me start a new career with the promise of it taking 4 months tops. Now it may take over a year!?!? I could do a Masters in that time. Just don't buy a course or track from them unless the ENTIRE lot is accessible upfront. Good content, but the service is a COMPLETE SCAM!

headline: Disgustingly poor support
reviewBody:
They either don't respond to your emails and if they do, they claim you're wrong.
I made them aware that I couldn't get a certificate because the cert was saying that the course was not available, when it was available and active. I paid for the course and it said that I had another 10 months to complete it. I made customer services aware of the problem with the certificate and they stated that the course isn't available and they don't know when it will be. I sent them proof that it is active and available, they then tell me that it's the wrong course and it's a different course I want with the same name. There is no other course with the same name!!! They kept telling me I was wrong and then ignored my emails asking for a refund within the 14 day period, so I was in my right within the terms and conditions for a refund. Then by magic a week later, the certificate is fixed and I can now claim it, however, they never sent me an email stating it was fixed and no apology for them being wrong and advising me incorrectly. They have no clue of their own products and will just shoo you away regardless if you're a paying customer or not.

headline: Incredibly bad support team :(
reviewBody:
I was a loyal customer for years. I invested 750 USD in edx.org because I believed in what they are doing.

However, I had a technical problem when clicking on "Upgrade to Verified". I always get "Server Error"; when looking at the http-requests I could see 500 errors. I even tested other courses (work fine) and I even created a test-account, enrolled to this course and could successfully click "Upgrade to Verified". So it was specific to the course and specific to my account.

I contacted support several times but always got the same answer. I should clear my cookies and the like. In fact I believe they aren't reading my support requests at all. I got the impression only if you reply to the first automated reply, then someone is really reading your support request.

However, their support seems so bad that someone really asked me to "change my internet service" after I provided technical screenshots and information :(.

So even when I can workaround this technical problem I am not willing to. I simply don't want to give a company money when they are treating me like this.

I'm sorry but I really can't recommend edx.org anymore.

headline: Content is Good, Support is Not
reviewBody:
The positives: If you don’t plan on going the paid route, there’s good material to learn from.

The negatives: They have a few bugs in their site, so deadline times and dates are not set properly for verification upgrades and course endings. Don’t even think about reaching out to support, as they do not offer any viable help. I completed (and paid for) 4/9 courses toward the UX MicroMasters. I was planning on upgrading to verified for the 5th course, and my account stated that the last day to upgrade was the 9th. I read this on the night of the 8th while stopped on a long 8 hour drive to see my family. I thought, “Great! I’ll upgrade tomorrow when I get there.” When I signed in the next day to upgrade, I was no longer given the option to do so. I immediately reached out to support via email and Facebook. The edX Facebook account just sends back an automated reply over and over again, and the support team told me there was nothing they could do and to keep my eye on future UX series. Really? I’m not going to spend more money on being treated the same way again in the future and wasting 400 dollars.

This is a poor way to treat a paying user that was within the upgrade window stated on the course. I will not be using edX in the future and I highly suggest for others to be weary before they pay.

headline: Project Management hell
reviewBody:
I signed up for a course last year.  It was a really good course and the instructor was flexible with being able to complete the required course work on time.  My work can sometimes cause me to be away for a few weeks.  It was a really good course.

However, I signed up for a course in project management this year.  OMG, the worse course EVER.  Not only that, I complained to EdX and to the instructor.  Noone would listen.  I am a verified student.  My work forces me to be away at times.  I know the course work can be completed before the end of the term.  If EdX is going to not allow someone to makeup missed work, they should state that rule clearly up front before someone spends alot of money for nothing.

headline: AUDIT but don't bother getting verified!
reviewBody: Don’t bother getting VERIFIED with a class on EdX. I learned the hard way. Invested money and most of all time only to learn that I did not pass the course. Should have just audited but I verified on the last day they offered the upgrade because I enjoyed the class and figured I’d get something to prove I took it. Was told by TA and professor that all was well and was successful with my final project. No reason to think otherwise. Passed in all work and assessments. The class itself was fine but the system EdX uses  is awful and clunky. If I saw any indication that I would not pass, I would have remedied that. Progress page doesn’t show final portfolio grade so had no reason to think I wouldn’t pass. I see some of my self-reports did not register in the system and I have proof I did them. Customer Serviice was NOT helpful — was told sorry, you didn’t pass, you will need to retake. Did not bother to answer my follow up questions. Glitchy system and horrible interface. Audit if you must because there are good classes, but don’t bother paying for it. Not worth aggravation. I’m upset mostly about the time invested and of course money I spent.
